ul:
PCI DSS Requirement 8.5.10 
    Microsoft Active Directory

For more information about enforcing password policy in a Microsoft AD environment, please see "Enforcing Strong Password Usage Throughout Your Organization" at
http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc875814.aspx
    To download the "Group Policy Management Console," please see "Group Policy Management Console with Service Pack 1" at

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?displaylang=en&FamilyID=0a6d4c24-8cbd-4b35-9272-dd3cbfc81887

Formulate the User Authentication and Password Policies
    
    
      Implement the Password Policy Using Group Policy Objects
li:
Launch the "Group Policy Management" console. The "Group Policy Management" console is included in Windows 2008, but has to be downloaded and installed on Windows 2003 and 2000. The link to the download is available at the bottom of this
 page. To launch the "Group Policy Management" console, execute the "gpmc.msc" command.
Launch the Group Policy Object Editor. Navigate to the "Group Policy Objects" folder under the current domain, right click on the GPO and select "Edit".

Verify that the "Minimum password length" policy is used. For each relevant domain, check that there is a linked group policy object that enables the "Minimum password length" policy. The "Minimum password length" policy is enabled by default
 on Windows 2003 and 2008 and is configured to require passwords to be at least 7 characters long. Verify that it has not been changed. The "Minimum password length" policy is included in the default GPO called “Default Domain Policy.” The "Minimum password
 length" policy can be found under “Windows Settings”, “Security Settings”, “Account Policies”, “Password Policy”, “Password must meet complexity requirements”.

Launch the "Group Policy Management" console. The "Group Policy Management" console is included in Windows 2008, but has to be downloaded and installed on Windows 2003 and 2000. The link to the download is available at the bottom of this
 page. To launch the "Group Policy Management" console, execute the "gpmc.msc" command.

Edit or create a Group Policy Object (GPO). To create and activate a new Group Policy Object (GPO), launch "The Group Policy Management" console, right click on the domain and select "Create and Link a GPO Here." To edit an existing GPO,
 navigate to the "Group Policy Objects" folder under the current domain, right click on the GPO and select "Edit" - this will open the "Group Policy Object Editor."

Configure the “Minimum password length” policy. Set the “Minimum password length” policy requirement to 7 characters or more. This setting is included in the default GPO called "Default Domain Policy." It is found under “Windows Settings”,
 “Security Settings”, “Account Policies”, “Password Policy”, “Password must meet complexity requirements”. The "Minimum password length" policy is enabled on Windows 2003 and 2008 by default and is configured to require passwords to be at least 7 characters
 long.
Link the GPO to the domain. Link an active group policy object that enables the "Minimum password length" policy to each relevant domain .

For more information about enforcing password policy in a Microsoft AD environment, please see "Enforcing Strong Password Usage Throughout Your Organization" at
http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc875814.aspx

To download the "Group Policy Management Console," please see "Group Policy Management Console with Service Pack 1" at

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?displaylang=en&FamilyID=0a6d4c24-8cbd-4b35-9272-dd3cbfc81887
Formulate the User Authentication and Password Policies
Implement the Password Policy Using Group Policy Objects

a: Formulate the User Authentication and Password Policies
Implement the Password Policy Using Group Policy Objects

links.text: Formulate the User Authentication and Password Policies
Implement the Password Policy Using Group Policy Objects

html:
Applies to

  • PCI DSS Requirement 8.5.10
  • Microsoft Active Directory

What to Check For

Only passwords that are at least seven characters long should be allowed.

Why

Using long passwords ensures that the passwords are hard to crack.

How to Check

Verify that the password length requirement is enforced by performing the following steps:

  1. Launch the "Group Policy Management" console. The "Group Policy Management" console is included in Windows 2008, but has to be downloaded and installed on Windows 2003 and 2000. The link to the download is available at the bottom of this page. To launch the "Group Policy Management" console, execute the "gpmc.msc" command.

  2. Launch the Group Policy Object Editor. Navigate to the "Group Policy Objects" folder under the current domain, right click on the GPO and select "Edit".

  3. Verify that the "Minimum password length" policy is used. For each relevant domain, check that there is a linked group policy object that enables the "Minimum password length" policy. The "Minimum password length" policy is enabled by default on Windows 2003 and 2008 and is configured to require passwords to be at least 7 characters long. Verify that it has not been changed. The "Minimum password length" policy is included in the default GPO called “Default Domain Policy.” The "Minimum password length" policy can be found under “Windows Settings”, “Security Settings”, “Account Policies”, “Password Policy”, “Password must meet complexity requirements”.

How to Fix

Use the following steps to configure the Active Directory to enforce the minimum password length requirement:

  1. Launch the "Group Policy Management" console. The "Group Policy Management" console is included in Windows 2008, but has to be downloaded and installed on Windows 2003 and 2000. The link to the download is available at the bottom of this page. To launch the "Group Policy Management" console, execute the "gpmc.msc" command.

  2. Edit or create a Group Policy Object (GPO). To create and activate a new Group Policy Object (GPO), launch "The Group Policy Management" console, right click on the domain and select "Create and Link a GPO Here." To edit an existing GPO, navigate to the "Group Policy Objects" folder under the current domain, right click on the GPO and select "Edit" - this will open the "Group Policy Object Editor."

  3. Configure the “Minimum password length” policy. Set the “Minimum password length” policy requirement to 7 characters or more. This setting is included in the default GPO called "Default Domain Policy." It is found under “Windows Settings”, “Security Settings”, “Account Policies”, “Password Policy”, “Password must meet complexity requirements”. The "Minimum password length" policy is enabled on Windows 2003 and 2008 by default and is configured to require passwords to be at least 7 characters long.

  4. Link the GPO to the domain. Link an active group policy object that enables the "Minimum password length" policy to each relevant domain .

Additional Resources

  • For more information about enforcing password policy in a Microsoft AD environment, please see "Enforcing Strong Password Usage Throughout Your Organization" at http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc875814.aspx
  • To download the "Group Policy Management Console," please see "Group Policy Management Console with Service Pack 1" at http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?displaylang=en&FamilyID=0a6d4c24-8cbd-4b35-9272-dd3cbfc81887

Related Items

  • Formulate the User Authentication and Password Policies
  • Implement the Password Policy Using Group Policy Objects
